newsitem.title: USA: FORECAST-US July durables to confirm soft economy.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-US July durables to confirm soft economy.

text.p: The U.S. durable goods report due out Friday should show orders rose slightly in July, but not enough to indicate an accelerating economy, analysts said.
"The data will likely confirm in the overall orders number that the economy was kind of sluggish in July," said Josh Feinman, global markets economist at BT Securities Inc.

In a Reuters survey, economists predicted a July durable goods orders rise of 0.3 percent. The ex-defense indicator is expected to post a 0.8 percent gain. Such a result would mark the third rise in durable goods orders this year.
In June the overall number declined 0.6 percent, to a seasonally-adjusted $169.19 billion, reflecting weaker demand for aircraft, cars and business equipment.
The Department of Commerce is due to publish the indicator on Friday, August 23 at 0830 EDT/1230 GMT.

Because of anecdotal evidence and other economic data, analysts already know "that consumer spending on durables was weak in July," Feinman said. "The new information is what the business investment spending was doing, which we don't really know. And we're going to get some of that on the non-defense capital portion" of the report, Feinman added.

Analysts said transport orders -- mainly in the aircraft sector -- are expected to remain fairly weak in July after a strong 4.2 percent jump in May that reflected a surge in commercial aircraft demand.
"We're looking for a drop in transportation orders ... mainly aircraft orders," said Cary Leahey, senior financial markets economist at Lehman Government Securities Inc.
"I'd say any ex-transportation number below 1.0 percent would not be a big surprise to the (financial) markets," Leahey added.
Capital goods are expected to show a fairly positive performance in July, but analysts said they did not expect scattered signs of economic strength to change the overall economic picture.
"The capital goods sector is okay ... (but) this is just another indication that while July was a weakish month overall there were some patches of strength," Leahey said.

Looking at the manufacturing sector as a whole, analysts said the durable goods report is likely to confirm an incipient slowdown as suggested by the National Association of Purchasing Management (NAPM) index in July.
The July NAPM index dropped to 50.2 from 54.3 in June. A reading below 50 is seen by the economists as an indication of a slowing manufacturing sector.
Looking at the broader picture, analysts said durable goods data could confirm the overall economy slowed in July, even if the overall headline number appears on the plus side.
"People are going to say it's still a soft economy because all it did was reverse last month's decline," said Steve Ricchiuto, chief financial economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Government Inc.
